abstract: The mixed news about the second quarter’s stock performance gets at three key questions every investor should answer: What benchmark should I use? What time period should I look at? Do I really care whether I beat the benchmark?
snippet: The mixed news about the second quarter’s stock performance gets at three key questions every investor should answer: What benchmark should I use? What time period should I look at? Do I really care whether I beat the benchmark?
lead_paragraph: It’s bittersweet news: the Dow Jones Industrial Average just finished its best quarter in more than five years. It’s up 29 percent since March 9. Of course we’d all be more excited about that if it weren’t still 40 percent below its Oct. 2007 peak.

headline.main: Is the Market Up 29 Percent or Down 40 Percent?

abstract: Wall Street ended the week with a sharp decline, spurred by the June jobless report. The Dow fell by more than 220 points.
snippet: Wall Street ended the week with a sharp decline, spurred by the June jobless report. The Dow fell by more than 220 points.
lead_paragraph: Fears that rising unemployment will prolong what is already a deep, painful recession sent stocks tumbling on Thursday and pushed the broad market into the red once again for the year.

headline.print_headline: Markets Fall Sharply on Report of 467,000 Job Losses in June

abstract: News Corp.’s chairman, Rupert Murdoch, said in an interview with TheStreet.com that he remains committed to MySpace, the social networking site, and isn’t interested in buying The New York Times Co.
snippet: News Corp.’s chairman, Rupert Murdoch, said in an interview with TheStreet.com that he remains committed to MySpace, the social networking site, and isn’t interested in buying The New York Times Co.
lead_paragraph: It’s been four years since Rupert Murdoch surprised the media world with his MySpace acquisition, and two years since he did it again with Dow Jones and The Wall Street Journal.

headline.main: Murdoch Says He’s Committed to MySpace
